title: feat: coerce float array for nearest query
Materialize deletions when updating scalar indices
body: When we update a scalar index we basically retrain it on the old data (which we scan from the old index, already sorted) and the new data (which we scan from the dataset, in sorted order).  While we are scanning the old data we scan both the value column and the row id column.  We can grab the deletion information for the affected fragments from the dataset and filter out rows based on the row id.  This should allow us to relatively cheaply materialize deletions at the same time we run an update.

title: convert yfcc subset - will not merge
body: just to make sure we can convert yfcc subset fast

title: chore: expose scalar index
body: expose scalar index APIs module.

title: feat: index cache size should be settable and readable in bytes
body: As per https://github.com/lancedb/lance/pull/1587 it is settable and readable in entry count.

title: fix: add migration for bad fragment bitmaps
Compaction should remove deleted fragments from an index when that index is remapped
body:
When we run compaction we remap the indices.  During this process we will remove any deleted rows that get materialized as part of the compaction process, simplifying the index and making it simpler to query.

However, we do not materialize any deleted fragments, even though we could.  By doing this we could restore index searches to the fast path even if a fragment is deleted.

title: bug: add a regression test for optimize_indices
body:
Add a regression test to catch index corruption issue when calling `optimize_indices`

TODO:
- [ ] add a corrupted dataset to `test_data`

title: fix: google objectstore uses proper gs configuration
body: gs was converting to azure options instead of gcs options.

title: fix: when we optimize indices we are incorrectly updating the list of indexed fragments
body: The current approach updates the indexed fragments to match the current dataset version.  This is incorrect because updating indices does not (necessarily) remove deleted fragments from the index data.  Instead we should only be adding new fragment ids to the index's fragment id list.

title: fix: fix a memory leak where a dataset would not be fully deleted
body:
If you create/open a dataset, search the dataset (using a vector index) and then drop the dataset it will leak some memory.  This is because the dataset has an index cache.  The index cache keeps strong pointers to the indices.  However, in the IVF case, we were also keeping a strong pointer to the index cache.  This caused a cycle and the index and cache kept themselves alive.

This fix downgrades the IVF index's pointer from `Arc` to `Weak` to break the cycle.  I've verified the fix manually but am not sure of a good way to detect this sort of thing in testing.  Perhaps we can investigate running valgrind?

title: Add documentation for debugging tools
body:
Logs are set by `LANCE_LOG`

`RUST_BACKTRACE` is helpful where there are crashes.

Maybe we should add these tips to GitHub issue template?

title: Fallback to searching more IVF partitions if there is a prefilter and we cannot get enough results
body: If there is a prefilter, especially if that prefilter is highly selective, there is a chance we will pick the wrong IVF partitions and not find any results.  In this case we should search more IVF partitions to try and find results.  Ideally, this would only be a failure behavior to cover unlikely scenarios and we can come up with better ways to pick which IVF partition to search in the presence of a prefilter.

title: Use bloom filters to determine IVF partitions when prefilter + scalar index
body:
When there is a very restrictive prefilter we risk picking the wrong IVF partitions and not finding the correct results.  One potential fix for this could be to keep a bloom filter of the row ids contained in each IVF partition.  Given our prefilter results we can then eliminate partitions from consideration if none of the allowed ids are contained in the bloom filter.

This is not a sure thing and I am mostly jotting this down as an idea.  There are still scenarios where this would not be helpful.  For example, if the prefilter is very restrictive but the filtered results are very evenly distributed across the IVF partitions then this will not help much (we'd pretty much need to search all of the partitions no matter what).  Other approaches, such as some kind of filter-aware IVF training, might be more effective.

Another potential solution would be to fallback to KNN if we find the prefilter is very selective.

title: Put a scan with filter benchmark on our website.
body:
Show with/without scalar indices.
Show with statistics.

title: feat: improve GPU memory usage to train large IVF
body:
# Problem Statement


Improve IVF usage to train large k-means on GPU.  For example, Lance usually requires sample `256 x #(IVF)` of vectors to train kmeans. For a large IVF like IVF65536, it will result about 100GB  just for training dataset. 

We don't really need to keep all the data in memory.

title: feat: add python bindings for creating scalar indices
feat: torch cache-able dataset, with sampling support
body:
Pytorch Dataset

* Work with PyTorch pipelines
* Local filesystem backed cache
* Faster pseudo random samplings. 
* Support project projection and filterings.

title: Refactor schema using arena tree
body:
I came across this Rust pattern described here: https://dev.to/deciduously/no-more-tears-no-more-knots-arena-allocated-trees-in-rust-44k6

Polars has a version of it here: https://github.com/pola-rs/polars/blob/main/crates/polars-utils/src/arena.rs#L30

Right now Lance schema is a little unwieldy. You can easily get the children of a field, but it's hard to go from child to parent. It's also hard to find a field by id. The nice thing about the arena style tree is is makes a lot of common operation (depth-first, find field by id) trivial and efficient.

body:

title: feat: make Dataset::nearest() accepts arbitrary query type
body: * Also makes all distant function returns `f32`, because it is the fastest type to do sorting later.

title: refactor: switch to using DataFusions physical expr
body: To make us more compatible with DataFusion, this PR refactors our handling of nested column references. We completely remove our `physical_expr` module in favor of existing DataFusion constructs. [Expr::GetIndexedField](https://docs.rs/datafusion/latest/datafusion/logical_expr/expr/enum.Expr.html#variant.GetIndexedField) is the DataFusion expression to handle nested field references.

title: Filter flat_knn when scalar index is more caught up than vector index
body: If the vector index is missing fragments then those fragments are run through a flat knn search.  The scalar index may or may not include those fragments.  Either way, we need to make sure we apply the prefilter to the flat knn data.

title: chore: dotprod should be on mac target, not haswell and better randomness for bf16
body: Generating bf16 from random f32's is biased.  Use random u16 as source instead.

title: chore: update cc dependency to 1.0.83
body: Our build script is using the `std` function which was added in [`1.0.83`](https://github.com/rust-lang/cc-rs/releases/tag/1.0.83)

title: feat: f16 for L2
feat: allow scalar indices to be updated with new data
body:
Training a scalar index is quick so on update we retrain.  We sort the new data and then read in the already sorted old data and train on the merged stream.

Closes #1568

title: perf: add bf16 benchmarks
feat: implement as_slice for bfloat16 array
feat: make IVF model support f16 and bf16
feat: extend FSL with sample
body: Add a `FixedSizeList::sample(n)` method.

title: feat: add support for remapping scalar indices during compaction
body: Closes #1567

title: Add scalar index support for individual fields within a nested field
body: #1569 looks to add support for scalar indices to struct types.  However, we should also be able to create a scalar index on one field of a struct.  For example, if we have an `Address` struct then we should be able to create a scalar index on `address.postal_code` for example.

title: Add scalar index support for complex types
body: Right now we've only really tested int/bool/float/string but we should be able to create an index on struct / list / etc.

title: Allow scalar indices to be updated
body: We should be able to retrain scalar indices quickly enough that we can just read the existing index in sorted order and sorting the new data and then merging the two sets.

title: Integrate scalar indices with index remapping
body: Right now we are not remapping scalar indices on compaction.  We will need to do so.

title: Use scalar indices even if there is new or deleted data
body: #1543 adds support for scalar indices to the scanner.  However, it only takes effect if there is no new or deleted data.  We should add logic to handle the cases where there is new or deleted data.

title: If there is a vector search then the output always contains the vector column even if not included in project
body:
We need to load the vector column to do the vector search so this isn't really a performance concern.  However, as a user, if I specifically list the columns I want, then I probably don't expect there to be extra columns (except _distance).

I've opened this as an issue as I'm not sure if this is expected behavior (in which case we should document it) or not (in which case we should fix it).

I do think there will be situations where users will want the vector search but not the vector column.  For example, maybe the vector column is an image embedding and the data they really want is the image itself or a URL for the image.

title: dataset.to_table().to_pandas() raise error `Io error: Execution error: LanceError(Arrow): Invalid argument error`
body:
example code
```
import lance
import pyarrow as pa
import numpy as np

train_data_size = 100000
test_data_size = 100
vector_dimension = 768
cluster_number = 10
cluster_size = train_data_size // cluster_number

train_data = []
for i in range(cluster_number):
    cluster_center = np.random.rand(vector_dimension)
    cluster_data = np.random.randn(cluster_size, vector_dimension) + cluster_center
    train_data.append(cluster_data)
# save train data to parquet file
train_data = np.concatenate(train_data)
train_data = np.array(train_data, dtype=np.float32)

table = pa.table({
   "id": pa.array([x for x in range(train_data_size)]),
   "embedding": pa.array(train_data.tolist())
})
dataset = lance.write_dataset(table, "embeddings")
df = dataset.to_table().to_pandas()
print(df.head())
```

error
```
Traceback (most recent call last):
 xxx
  File "pyarrow/ipc.pxi", line 750, in pyarrow.lib.RecordBatchReader.read_all
  File "pyarrow/error.pxi", line 100, in pyarrow.lib.check_status
pyarrow.lib.ArrowInvalid: C Data interface error: Io error: Execution error: LanceError(Arrow): Invalid argument error: Last offset 6290688 of List(Field { name: "item", data_type: Float64, nullable: true, dict_id: 0, dict_is_ordered: false, metadata: {} }) is larger than values length 8192
```

title: Empty prefiltering criteria results in exception
body:
(from user report)

# Problem

Using prefiltering, if the filter results in an empty set, then an exception is raised.

# Expected behavior

Return an empty arrow table

# Stacktrace

```
File /usr/local/lib/python3.8/dist-packages/lance/dataset.py:308, in LanceDataset.to_table(self, columns, filter, limit, offset, nearest, batch_size, batch_readahead, fragment_readahead, scan_in_order, prefilter, with_row_id)
    247 def to_table(
    248     self,
    249     columns: Optional[list[str]] = None,
   (...)
    260     with_row_id: bool = False,
    261 ) -> pa.Table:
    262     """Read the data into memory as a pyarrow Table.
    263 
...
File /usr/local/lib/python3.8/dist-packages/pyarrow/ipc.pxi:754, in pyarrow.lib.RecordBatchReader.read_all()

File /usr/local/lib/python3.8/dist-packages/pyarrow/error.pxi:115, in pyarrow.lib.check_status()

OSError: Io error: Execution error: External error: Execution error: LanceError(IO): Execution error: Failed to compute distances: LanceError(Arrow): Schema error: Can not append column _distance on schema: Schema { fields: [Field { name: "_distance", data_type: Float32, nullable: true, dict_id: 0, dict_is_ordered: false, metadata: {} }, Field { name: "_rowid", data_type: UInt64, nullable: true, dict_id: 0, dict_is_ordered: false, metadata: {} }, Field { name: "image_intro", data_type: FixedSizeList(Field { name: "item", data_type: Float32, nullable: true, dict_id: 0, dict_is_ordered: false, metadata: {} }, 1280), nullable: true, dict_id: 0, dict_is_ordered: false, metadata: {} }], metadata: {} }, /home/runner/work/lance/lance/rust/lance-index/src/vector/flat.rs:57:36, /home/runner/work/lance/lance/rust/lance/src/io/exec/take.rs:72:42
```

# Reproduction

user report:

"""
I reproduced with:
Do a normal index search, and the result looks good.
Add a filter that has obviously incorrect condition, such as start_time stamp is larger than end_time stamp, the error raises
"""

Confirmed that this was using prefilter=True. When prefilter=True is removed, it won't raise error

title: feat: ffi to accelerate norm_l2 for f16 if the instruction set is available
If there is new data, and a prefilter, then the new data is not being prefiltered
body:
Given a dataset that has new data, and a nearest/vector query that has a prefilter, then the new data is not being subjected to the prefilter and may be incorrectly returned.  The query plan generated is:

```
Projection: fields=[vector, indexed, not_indexed, _distance]
  Take: columns="_distance, _rowid, vector, indexed, not_indexed"
    KNNFlat: k=10 metric=l2
      RepartitionExec: partitioning=RoundRobinBatch(1), input_partitions=2
        UnionExec
          Projection: fields=[_distance, _rowid, vector]
            KNNFlat: k=10 metric=l2 <--- THERE SHOULD BE A FILTER JUST BEFORE HERE
              LanceScan: uri=tmp/.tmpLth8FX/data, projection=[vector], row_id=true, ordered=false
          Take: columns="_distance, _rowid, vector"
            KNNIndex: name=6d1cb8b7-ec0a-4255-b0bd-c48c1b76c3c8, k=10
              FilterExec: indexed != 50
                LanceScan: uri=tmp/.tmpLth8FX/data, projection=[indexed], row_id=true, ordered=true
```

title: Support basic update transaction
body:
As in SQL `UPDATE table WHERE <condition> SET <new values>`.

Out of scope: compaction-on-write, re-indexing.

title: Scalar index follow-up issues tracker
body:
This is a meta issue to track the various follow-ups that have emerged as I have been working on scalar indices:

Finishing Functionality

 - [ ] #1566
 - [x] #1567 
 - [x] #1568 

Complex Scalar Indices

- [ ] #1569 
- [ ] #1570

Complex Index Queries

 - [ ] #1549 
 - [ ] #1550 

Index Performance Improvements

 - [ ] #1551 
 - [ ] #1552 
 - [ ] #1657

title: Store a compressed bitmap alongside the index pages
body:
When we match a page in the btree search we then delegate to the sub-index to search that page.  This works well for high cardinality data and equality / inequality searches.  However, it can be inefficient when the data is low cardinality since we have to search a very large page (or many small pages)

Luckily, when we search the btree, we can know if a page is entirely included in the result.  In other words, if a page has `min: 5, max: 10` and the query is `value < 20` then we don't need to search the page because we know we want all of the rows in the page.  If we had stored a compressed bitmap of all the row ids in the page then all we would need to do would be to load that.

title: Merge scalar index pages when all values are the same
body:
Right now, when training a scalar btree index, we always divide the input up into evenly sized pages.  For example, given an input of `[1, 2, 2, 2, 2, 2, 2, 2, 2, 2, 5, 10]` and a page size of 3 we would create pages:

```
[1, 2, 2]
[2, 2, 2]
[2, 2, 2]
[2, 5, 10]
```

There is no advantage to having multiple pages that are all the same value.  Ideally we would create pages like:

```
[1]
[2, 2, 2, 2, 2, 2, 2, 2, 2]
[5, 10]
```

This way, if the filter is `x = 2` then we only need to read one page instead of reading three pages.  It would also simplify the logic in the btree index lookup.

This may seem like an unlikely occurrence but it is very common when we have low cardinality columns since we sort those columns first.  In other words, if we have a column that only has 5 choices, we should only have five pages, even if we have 100 million rows.

title: Support logical OR of `IndexedExpression` when there is both a `scalar_query` and a `refine`
body:
Currently we do not take advantage of the index when the query is something like this (assume "color" is indexed and "size" is not indexed)

```
(color == 'blue' AND size < 20) OR (color == 'red' AND size < 50)
```

We should be able to rewrite this to:

```
(color == 'blue' OR color == 'red') AND ((color == 'blue' AND size < 20) OR (color == 'red' AND size < 50))
```

The first part can become an index lookup and then the second part can become the refine expression.

title: Support normalization / simplification before looking for indexable expressions in a query
body:
This is a follow-up opportunity from #1543 which is adding support for using scalar indices in queries with filters.

In #1543 the queries are not normalized / simplified before they are checked for indexable expressions.  This means a filter like `x + 3 = 7` won't be recognized even though we should be able to fully satisfy that filter with an index search (assuming there is a scalar index for `x`).

We should be able to use something like https://docs.rs/datafusion/latest/datafusion/optimizer/simplify_expressions/struct.ExprSimplifier.html#method.simplify to do this for us.

title: feat: allow for more advanced storage options in objectstore
body:
closes https://github.com/lancedb/lance/issues/1542

This takes a few components, and a lot of inspiration from the delta-rs implementation. The idea being it'll make it easier for others to adopt if it's familiar to other data formats (_with delta being the closest in nature to lance_).


Overall, I think these changes make it not only much more ergonomic, but also much easier to fine tune the lower level object store settings. 


### Some top level functions exposed that mirror delta-rs. 
```rust
let path = "gs://my-bucket/my_table.lance";
// using the default storage options
let dataset = lance::open_dataset(path).await.unwrap();

// using custom storage options
let mut options: HashMap<String, String> = HashMap::new();
options.insert(
    "service_account_path".into(),
    "~/.service_acct_key.json".into(),
);
let dataset = lance::open_dataset_with_storage_options(path, options.clone())
    .await
    .unwrap();
```

### Additionally a `DatasetBuilder` for even more control. 

```rust
    // using the dataset builder
    use lance::{dataset::builder::DatasetBuilder, Dataset};

    let dataset: Dataset = DatasetBuilder::from_uri(path)
        .with_block_size(1024 * 4)
        .with_index_cache_size(0)
        .with_storage_options(options)
        .load()
        .await
        .unwrap();
```

### Original functionality is still retained.

```rust
let dataset = Dataset::open(path).await.unwrap();
```

A lot of the original functionality _could_ be deprecated and removed as there is some duplication now. But I didn't want to break anything within the bindings libraries, or otherwise introduce a breaking change. 

Still todo:

- [x] combine `ObjectStoreParams` with my new `ObjectStoreOptions` 


---
## Suggested Follow ups
now that we have a simpler builder pattern for initializing the `Dataset` and `ObjectStore`, we could deprecate & remove many of the now redundant factory methods

for example, `Dataset` has 4 different factory methods that can now be initialized via the builder instead

- `Dataset::open`
- `Dataset::open_with_params`
- `Dataset::checkout`
- `Dataset::checkout_with_params`

Similarly, `ObjectStore` has many factory methods as well that can be replaced by using the builder. 

- `ObjectStore::from_uri`
- `ObjectStore::from_uri_and_params`
- `ObjectStore::from_path`
- `ObjectStore::new_from_path`
- `ObjectStore::new_from_url`

title: allow more configuration options for ObjectStore
body:
Currently there are little options available for creating an `ObjectStore`. Especially if you want to customize the underlying `OSObjectStore`. 

The use case I am facing is using a google cloud object store. The current implementation will **always** read it from the env. I'd like to be able to either pass in the `OSObjectStore` directly, or allow for more customization. 

The [DeltaTableBuilder](https://github.com/delta-io/delta-rs/blob/main/crates/deltalake-core/src/table/builder.rs#L146) is a good example. It provides many utility options for customizing the underlying object store.

title: fix: pq index does not handle dot product metric correctly during search
Create a test framework to validate compatibility between Lance versions
body:
We currently only test with a single Lance version, but there can be incompatibilities between versions that we need to test for. Right now we can only do so manually.

We can start checking in tables from different versions of Lance that are important. These can be copied and uses as the basis for testing migrations and backwards compatibility. For example, pylance 0.7.5 is the last version before we started tracking `physical_rows` on fragments, so we'll want a table from that version so we can check we can successfully migrate from there.

title: fix: add versioning and bypass broken row counts
body:
Adds a new feature: `WriterVersion` in the manifest.

Also fixes two bugs:
* #1531 Adds bypass logic to read correct `physical_rows` when old version is detected.
  Will update the value on write as needed.
* When `migrate_fragments` runs, we do it on the new fragments and not the old,
  fixing a data loss issue.

Fixes #1531
Fixes #1535

title: feat: make L2 generic to work with all float numbers
Incorrect physical_rows recorded when migrating from old versions of tables with deletions
body:
v0.8.0: We started recording the number of physical rows, but implementation used `count_rows()` to compute this.
v0.7.5 is the version right before that.

## How to reproduce

Install pylance 0.7.5
```shell
python -m venv .venv
source .venv/bin/activate
pip install pylance==0.7.5
python
```

Write a table, and delete some rows
```python
import lance
import pyarrow as pa

tab = pa.table({'x': range(100)})
dataset = lance.write_dataset(tab, 'test')
dataset.delete("x >= 10 and x < 20")
dataset.count_rows()
```

```
90
```

Now, install pylance 0.8.0:
```shell
pip install pylance==0.8.0
python
```

Count rows at first is correct. However, once we write to the table, it becomes incorrect:
```python
import lance
import pyarrow as pa

dataset = lance.dataset('test')
dataset.count_rows() # 90

tab = pa.table({'x': range(5)})
dataset = lance.write_dataset(tab, 'test', mode='append')
dataset.count_rows() # 85 
dataset.to_table().num_rows # 95
```

title: fix: fix assertion of cosine values
feat: safer API for physical_rows
body:
Issues like https://github.com/lancedb/lance/pull/1511 have shown the APIs where `0` is a sentinel value are dangerous and often mis-used. This PR changes `Fragment.physical_rows` and `DeletionFile.num_deleted_rows` to use `Option` instead, which forces the unknown case to be recognized and handled. This fixes some bugs in the handling of those.

There is another bug mentioned, but that is saved for another PR.

title: Write a Lance TableProvider
body: This will allow us to use LanceTables as input to DataFusion queries. This can make it easier for us to write efficient ETL jobs and also pave the way for a more fully-featured SQL engine if we want to go that route.

title: create_index lies about schema it is writing
body:
If we compare the schema expected (left) to schema found in data (right), they do not match. I found this bug when implementing statistics, where we need the schemas to be correct.

```
pyo3_runtime.PanicException: assertion `left == right` failed
E         left: Schema { fields: [Field { name: "_rowid", data_type: UInt64, nullable: true, dict_id: 0, dict_is_ordered: false, metadata: {} }, Field { name: "__pq_code", data_type: FixedSizeList(Field { name: "item", data_type: UInt8, nullable: true, dict_id: 0, dict_is_ordered: false, metadata: {} }, 2), nullable: false, dict_id: 0, dict_is_ordered: false, metadata: {} }], metadata: {} }
E        right: Schema { fields: [Field { name: "_rowid", data_type: UInt64, nullable: true, dict_id: 0, dict_is_ordered: false, metadata: {} }, Field { name: "__ivf_part_id", data_type: UInt32, nullable: false, dict_id: 0, dict_is_ordered: false, metadata: {} }, Field { name: "__pq_code", data_type: FixedSizeList(Field { name: "item", data_type: UInt8, nullable: true, dict_id: 0, dict_is_ordered: false, metadata: {} }, 2), nullable: false, dict_id: 0, dict_is_ordered: false, metadata: {} }], metadata: {} }
```

See reproduction in #1518

title: fix: tell writer correct schema when writing index file
body:
This adds schema enforcement to the file writer and shuffler.

Fixes #1519.

title: String stats always increments max value
body:
The string statistics always increments the max value, regardless of whether it is truncated: 

https://github.com/lancedb/lance/blob/4f7fb490c6b36a659b2c40b3945b4d533356acf2/rust/lance-core/src/io/writer/statistics.rs#L278

This should only be necessary if max value is longer than the limit.

This is problematic because we want to maintain the property that if all values are equal to X, then the min and max are both X (assuming X is within the binary size limit).
